texts.shortText: Very large, well-known, firm-bodied and active worm with an iridescent blue-brown sheen and often a white bar across the 5th body segment. Head with rounded palps and five finger-like antennae. Next two segments lack lateral appendages (parapodia), but possess a pair of short dorsal tentacular cirri. Feathery gills start to arise from lateral appendages from about segment 8 backwards.
Body length typically about 200 mm, but can be much larger.

Global: Widespread across North Atlantic, Caribbean, Indian Ocean, Red Sea, New Zealand, South Africa, etc.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

The largest regional polychaete and indeed the largest in the world (if it is believed that all worms bearing this name belong to the same species), the longest recorded specimen being neatly 3 m in length! Live in mucus-lined tubes excavated in sand and gravel between boulders. Sought after as bait and excavation by bait collectors causes considerable damage to the restricted habitats where these worms live. Possess formidable jaws and can inflict a painful bite.

Voracious carnivores, pouncing on passing prey from within the burrow and dragging the victims back underground. Documented feeding on fish in other regions, but this not observed locally to our knowledge.
Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Eggs have been observed lining the burrows, but it is assumed these develop into planktonic larvae.

The extremely large size, distinctive colour pattern and habits of this species are fairly distinctive, but it is very unlikely that the populations around the world that carry this name all indeed represent the same species. There are also several regional species in the genus.

Marphya species are similar, but smaller and they lack the tentacular cirri on segments 2-3.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part1 Errantia (p. 389).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 76).

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
